front.div:
We report a unique substrate for surface-enhanced raman spectroscopy ͑SERS͒ based on silver
nanoparticles-embedded silicon nanowires ͑SiNWs͒. The SiNWs were prepared by thermal
evaporation of SiO powder via oxide-assisted growth, oxide removed with HF, and then used to
reduce silver ions to form a highly decorated Ag-embedded surface. Such modified SiNWs
substrates yielded ultrahigh SERS sensitivity, which could detect 25 ␮l of 1ϫ 10
−16 M Rhodamine
6G, 1 ϫ 10
−16 M crystal violet, and 1 ϫ 10
−14 M nicotine in methanol solutions. An Ag-modified
SiNW strand could also enable SERS detection of 25 ␮l of 1ϫ 10
−8 mg/ ml calf thymus DNA. The
possible mechanisms for the ultrahigh SERS sensitivity were discussed.

Raman spectroscopy is a powerful technique to investi-
gate biological and chemical materials because it can provide
both rich structural and quantitative information in a nonde-
structive manner. It is widely recognized that Raman signals
can be readily enhanced by a factor of 10
6 –10
8 via proper
treatment of nanostructured metallic substrate for analytes,
coined as surface-enhanced raman spectroscopy ͑SERS͒.
